summary: A brain tumor is an abnormal growth of cells in the brain tissues, which can be benign (non-cancerous) or malignant (cancerous). They are classified as primary (originating in the brain) or secondary (metastatic, spreading from other parts of the body). Symptoms vary based on tumor size and location, and can include headaches, seizures, and cognitive changes.
causes: CT scan radiation (up to 4% of brain cancers)
Ionizing radiation (including radiation treatment for other cancers)
Mutations and deletions of tumor suppressor genes (e.g., P53)
symptoms: Headaches (often in the morning, worsened by Valsalva maneuver, causing awakening from sleep, progressively worsening, subsiding after vomiting, due to raised intracranial pressure)
Speech difficulties (e.g., decreased production, difficulty speaking, poor language interpretation)
Vision problems (e.g., poor vision, vision loss, visual abnormalities)
Cognitive impairment (e.g., problems with thinking, poor reasoning, poor planning, poor memory, difficulty recognizing)
Behavioral changes (e.g., inappropriate social behavior, personality changes, temper tantrums, lower inhibition)
Cranial nerve palsies (e.g., facial paralysis, abnormal eye movement, swallowing difficulty)
diagnosis: Magnetic Resonance Imaging (MRI) (with contrast enhancement, T1, T2, FLAIR imaging)
Magnetic Resonance Angiography (MRA) (with or without gadolinium contrast)
Perfusion Magnetic Resonance Imaging (pMRI) (with gadopentetate dimeglumine contrast)
Computed Tomography (CT) scan (with iodine-based or barium sulfate contrast)
Positron Emission Tomography (PET) scan (using radiolabelled substances like FDG)
Liquid biopsy (experimental, from blood, CSF, urine)
treatments: Surgery (resection, gross total resection, cytoreduction/debulking, minimally invasive techniques, trans-nasal trans-sphenoidal approach, craniotomy)

Radiation therapy (radiotherapy, external beam radiation therapy, whole-brain radiotherapy treatment/WBRT, whole-brain irradiation, radiosurgery, stereotactic radiosurgery, Gamma knife, Cyberknife, Novalis Tx radiosurgery, brachytherapy, proton therapy, hypofractionated radiation therapy, postoperative radiotherapy)
Chemotherapy (postoperative chemotherapy, chemotherapy agents like temozolomide)
Retroviral replicating vectors (experimental, Toca 511 & Toca FC)
